p.em: This course addresses topics in computer science that are beyond the scope of the AP and Honors computer science curricula. Topics include Event Driven programming, Graphical User Interface design and programming, Client/Server and Web programming, Database Connectivity, and Multi-Threaded programming. These topics will enable students to design and develop software solutions that are more comprehensive and realworld based compared to the AP and Honors courses.

page.p: Assignments will be given throughout the course. Most will be computer based assignments. Assignments will have a due date and will lose points if turned in late. Students are encouraged to work together on assignments as long as all students type their own work rather than copying work from other students. Work that has been copied electronically from another source will not receive credit and will not be eligible to be made up. Turning in electronic copies of work from another source will also be subject to further disciplinary action.

You are expected to be in class everyday. If you miss class, it is your responsibility to find out what you missed (copy notes from someone). You have one more day than the number of days absent to make up all missed work. (Example: if you are absent three days, you have four days to make up all the work. Any work that is not turned in or taken in those four days will count as a zero.)
You are expected to be in class at the scheduled time. Tardy is defined as not being in the classroom when the bell rings. All tardies will be handled as per the school's policy for tardies.

Assignments will have point values and will receive points based on the quality of work turned in. Students will have the opportunity to fix errors in assignments and resubmit them within a reasonable timeframe. The course follows the standard grading scale:
A: 90.0%-100%, B: 80%-89.9%, C: 70%-79.9%, D: 60%-69.9%, F: Below 60%.
There will be a final exam in the form of a project. The official semester grade will be calculated as 45% from each quarter in the semester (two quarters per semester), and 10% from the final exam.

I am available in room 304 (computer lab) at least 30 minutes before school. Students who need more individualized time are encouraged to make arrangements with me to meet at a mutually agreed upon time.

Grades are available for viewing through Family Access on the Internet. Grades are updated weekly, usually over the weekend. If you cannot access your grade through family access, or have any questions about your grade, please contact me directly.

The academic honesty policy as set forth by the school (on page 21 of the Student Planner and Handbook) will be used in this class. Specifically, immediate action will be taken for any student suspected of cheating on an assignment or test.
